summary: This is an email chain from August 2019 regarding the updating of an 'Institution Supplement' for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, specifically concerning patient care directives and Naloxone procedures. The email shows internal prison administration coordination shortly before Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody.

persons.name: Associate Warden MCC New York
persons.context: The sender of the email, coordinating the review of an updated Institution Supplement concerning patient care and Naloxone procedures at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

persons.name: Commander
persons.context: A recipient of the email, asked to review the updated Institution Supplement for accuracy and changes.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: A recipient of the email, asked to review the updated medical procedures, specifically the Naloxone details added to the supplement.

connections.description: The Associate Warden is requesting the Commander's review of an institutional document, indicating a working relationship within the prison administration.
The Associate Warden is requesting the Dr.'s review of updated medical procedures, indicating a professional working relationship.

events.title: Supplement Update Sent for Review
events.description: The Associate Warden updated an 'Institution Supplement' concerning patient care directives and Naloxone procedures and sent it to a Commander and a Dr. for review.

events.title: Email Coordination on Procedures
events.description: An email is sent forwarding the previous day's update, urging review of the supplement 'asap' to finalize the procedures.

locations.context: The address of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, the federal jail where Jeffrey Epstein was held and died.

keyFacts: The document is internal prison correspondence from August 14-15, 2019, just days before Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.
It shows active review and updating of patient care procedures and Naloxone (an opioid overdose reversal drug) protocols at the MCC New York.
The urgency expressed ('We have to get this done asap') suggests administrative pressure to finalize medical care directives at the facility.
The document does not mention Jeffrey Epstein by name, but its context and timing place it within the administrative operations of the jail where he was incarcerated.
